title: unconfirmed-reports-serious-injury-kelso-races
story: UPDATE: JOCKEY Conner McCann required medical attention following a fall at the second flight in the mf handicap hurdle at Kelso this afternoon.He was riding Diamond State.McCann was attended to by medical staff on the course.The air ambulance arrived shortly after pm.It is now understood that Conner left the race ground in a vehicle ambulance and not the air ambulance.Racing has now resumed.More to follow:

title: jockey-regains-consciousness-asks-whether-horse-ok
story: A TEENAGE jockey’s first words after regaining consciousness following an horric fall at Kelso races on Saturday  were to enquire for the welfare of his horse.Conner McCannfell at the second jump while riding Diamond State and was treated on the track.The teenager who has gained four wins from just  rides over jumps, had only just ed to action the previous day at Musselburgh having been out injured since January.An air ambulance was called and arrived shortly after pm. After assessment he was taken to hospital in a vehicle ambulance.He is currently in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh with two broken ribs, three fractures in his thoracic vertebrae and a suspected fracture in his c vertebrae along with a tiny fracture of his fibula. Thankfully there was no sign of any head injury.His first words on regaining consciousness were: “How’s Diamond  Is my horse OK  Are you sure he’s OK ”⭕️ There were y delays to racing at Kelso today as conditional jockey Conner McCann required medical attention following a fall— Racing PostMarch , Hundreds of followers took to social media to wish him a speedy recovery.Kelso Racecourse tweeted: “We have our fingers crossed that Conner is okay and we are all sending our very best wishes.”Racing TV tweeted: “Sending our very best wishes to Conner McCann, who is conscious and being taken to hospital for further assessment after his fall at @KelsoRacecourse.”

title: tour-britain-road-cycling-event-returns-scottish-borders-year
story: WORLD-CLASS road cycling willto the Scottish Borders this year when the area hosts the prestigious Tour of Britain and Tour Series events.Galashiels will welcome Britain’s leading male and female cyclists when it hosts the Tour Series, the fun, free and family-friendly cycling event, on Wednesday  May.Launched in , the series sees Britain’s best male and female riders compete against each other in a unique, team-based format as part of a full day of sporting and community-focused activities.British sporting heroes Laura Kenny, Tom Pidcock, Dani Rowe, Joanna Rowsell, Ed Clancy, Elinor Barker and Katie Archibald have all competed in the series during its history.Gala will become the sixth Scottish host venue with this new-for- round taking place on a technical circuit that starts and finishes adjacent to the idyllic Bank Street gardens.Riders will also pass by the Burgh Chambers and War Memorial, and the Great Tapestry of Scotland Visitor Centre during the one-kilometrelap that twists its way through the town.Stage two of the Tour of Britain – the UK’s most prestigious cycle race – will then take place solely within the Scottish Borders on Monday  September.The Borders have previously welcomed the race on eight occasions, including a stage start in Hawick last year, as well as a stage that started and finished in Kelso in .Mick Bennett, Tour of Britain and Tour Series race director said: “Few places lend themselves more to cycling than the Scottish Borders, owing to the mix of historic, unforgettable towns and stunning countryside roads. To be able to take the Tour Series there for the first time andwith the Tour of Britain once again shows the appetite for our world-famous events in the area. My gratitude goes out to everybody at the Scottish Borders Council for their continued support, dedication and passion.”Sam Smith, Scottish Borders Council’s Chief Officer for Economic Development added: “We are delighted to be able to bring back the Tour of Britain to the Borders again this year, and to be hosting a round of the televised Tour Series for the first time too..remove“These will be fantastic occasions for the area and will bring in visitors and provide great exposure for the Borders, further strengthening our position as Scotland’s leading cycling destination.“I’d like to thank our partners Live Borders and Energise Galashiels for their support in bringing the Tour Series to Galashiels and their commitment to help make it an amazing event for the community and visitors.”Highlights of both the men’s and women’s Tour Series races will once again be broadcast on ITV.

title: drivers-advised-use-caution-due-foggy-conditions-across-borders
story: DRIVERS in Scottish Borders are advised to use caution due to fog affecting driving conditions in the region.Traffic Scotland issued the advice earlier this morning. Drivers should drive slower and watch carefully the road in front because fog can appear and disappear in an instant.They should use rear fog lights when visibility reduced to m or less and only use front fog lights when visibility is seriously reduced.Drivers are also advised to turn the radio off and open a window slightly to hear other vehicles.It is important not follow the car in front too closely.Drivers should not use full beam head lights but dipped as these point to the road making it easier to see and for others to see them.It is also important to use windscreen wipers and demisters.If visibility reduced to less than  m then the vehicle’s speed should be mph.

title: scottish-governments-yours-use-kids-go-free-weekend
story: THIS weekendchildren between the ages of  and  will be able travel anywhere in the country for free, enabling families to adventure away from home and spend some quality time together this Easter break.The initiative is being funded by the Scottish Government to mark the historic change for ScotRail and ensuring that in its first weekend of operation as a public railway, ScotRail’s focus is firmly on future generations of rail passengers.The ‘Yours to Use’ Kids Go Free weekend will allow families to discover the joy of train travel, giving them a chance to set off and explore new places. With the offer, up to four children can travel for free with each fare-paying adult, encouraging more families to travel on Scotland’s tracks and discover the country’s hidden gems.Along with enabling children, parents, and carers to rediscover their sense of adventure, the offer hopes to persuade families to consider more sustainable forms of travel and leaving the car at home. ScotRail is committed to achieving net zero by  and is cutting carbon emissions by more than , tonnes a year - equivalent to removing , cars from the road every year.Scotrail Jenny Gilruth, Minister for Transport, said: “From  April Scotland’s Railways come into public ownership – as le begins toto normal, we want to do all we can to make rail an attractive choice for everyone - that includes families and friends looking to enjoy time together over the Easter holidays.“This offer is an early taste of the passenger focused approach we will be taking to support leisure travel as we move ScotRail forward under public control. I’d encourage as many people as possible to get out and about and enjoy all that Scotland’s Railway has to offer by taking advantage of our ‘’Yours to Use’ Kids Go Free weekend.”Lesley Kane, ScotRail Commercial Director, said: “Le is busy, especially when kids are involved, so we are delighted to be able to play our part in helping families make the most of the Easter break together by offering a ‘Kids Go Free’ weekend..remove“There’s a lot to be said about travelling by train with the family. From the excitement of exploring new places, to the journey itself, there’s certainly plenty to keep kids entertained. It also means parents get a chance to relax with less time spent behind the wheel.“We hope this offer encourages families to get onboard, enjoy a little escape this weekend, and spend some quality time together.”The ‘Yours to Use’ Kids Go Free offer can be redeemed alongside most adult tickets until Sunday,  April by simply downloading a voucher from the www.scotrail kidsgofree.Children must be accompanied by a fare-paying adult. Under s are already eligible for free train travel.Terms and conditions apply.

title: leader march 4 2022
story: Ukraine may be fighting one of the biggest and most powerful countries on earth, but it has the strength of the world behind it.The conflict has been described as a #David versus Goliath# war, with Ukraine battling to hold off the armies of its vast neighbour.Despite everything the country is going through, Ukraine#s leaders, military personnel and civilians have proved themselves to be tenacious, resilient, brave – and humorous!Videos showing Ukrainian soldiers dancing to pop music have gone viral on social media, with their ability to live in the moment earning them fans around the globe.Just last year, Ukraine celebrated  years of independence and now its sovereignty is being threatened in the worst way.The preservation of human le should come before all , and any military intervention by NATO countries would undoubtedly increase the death toll exponentially by turning the situation into a global conflict.Will the rest of the continent sit back indefinitely and do nothing but send weapons and impose sanctions while a European country battles for its existence

title: leader march 11 2022
story: One of the five tenets of taekwon-do is indomitable spirit.That is something which has been displayed in abundance in the last two weeks, since Russian forces invaded Ukraine.Despite all they are currently facing, Ukrainian soldiers took time on Tuesday, on International Women#s Day, to hand flowers to women they stopped at checkpoints.Viral videos of off-duty Ukrainian soldiers dancing in their unorms continue to flood social media.And, amid leading the fight against Russian invaders and holding meetings with world leaders, the country#s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, welcomed the start of spring in an outdoors video, ending the broadcast with a wink to the camera.The strength of spirit Ukrainians continue to show, from the bottom to the very top, should be an inspiration to us all.Kintyre has already shown incredible community spirit in its response to the crisis – well done to every person who contributed.And, although it might not effect change on a global scale, SG Taekwon-Do#s display of support for Ukraine shows that there are people in every corner of the world willing to stand up for democracy and what they believe is right.

title: letters march 11 2022
story: The Campbeltown Courier printed a story in February  about a painting, Village in the Valley, by H Shapiro.A reader then wrote to you, letting you know that the painting was by Hyman Shapiro and informed you that he had three children.I am one of Hyman Shapiro#s granddaughters. He had five children, not three.Before he was married to Gretl, the potter mentioned in the reader#s letter, he had two daughters, Gladys and Ruth, by his first we, Margaret, who died of tuberculosis.My mother Ruth, like her father, is a talented artist who has exhibited paintings.My we had to call the emergency services for me last Friday night at .am and,  minutes later, an ambulance arrived and the two paramedics provided me with great care and attention before transporting me to Campbeltown Hospital.I would like to thank them for the care and attention given to me.They do not receive as much gratitude from the public as they should and I would like to put on record my heartfelt thanks for their dedication and help in a very stressful period.Do the people of Campbeltown and her surrounding South Kintyre communities truly believe local frustrations are being heard in Kilmory Or have our three sitting councillors been napping this past decade, resting on their laurels, in the belief they are unaccountable to voters.It has been  years since the people of South Kintyre have voted in a local election. If you want to continue having the same conversations, raising the same issues, exasperated with the same results, thenthe same trio at the polls on May  and expect the same for the next five years.As a young man, I made a commitment to serve my country as a Royal Marines Commando now, I am prepared to make that same commitment to my community.I promise to proudly serve the people of South Kintyre to the best of my ability and present a strong new Conservative Unionist voice.If we do not meet on the doorstep in the coming months, can I encourage you to make your mark, on May , for a positive change to South Kintyre#s immediate future.I write after thousands of pounds worth of educational books were thrown in the bin in Oban.It is essential that our council#s leadership makes sure that hard-pressed council taxpayers are being provided with value for money. This in my opinion is a prime example of a failure to do so.The council leader talks a great deal about environmentalism but how is this environmental This is particularly saddening given the fact that so many teachers often struggle for ample educational booklets.My constituents are asking why our council taxes are having to go up when mountains of perfectly good books are being thrown in the skip It is beyond belief that this can be allowed to happen. These expensive books could be put to much better use than this.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022
story: Who am I  What am I  Where am I  How am I  – questions of identity and some of the questions I was left asking when I left a recent meeting.That meeting was part of a world-wide movement – a movement that calls the peoples of the world to pray.Similar questions of identity were raised when I was asked to write ‘a piece’ for this newspaper. The questions weren’t so much about me but you – who are you  What are you  Where are you  And how are you I can answer the questions about ‘me’ relatively easily, knowing that others might disagree. But I cannot so easily answer such questions about you for I don’t really know who reads this column.Identity, human identity, all of us wrestle with questions of identity – from the inidual to a community to a nation or a race.Who are the Scots  Who are the Ukrainians  Who are the Russians  Where do you come from The answers are never as simple as we think they might be or would like them to be.Humanity is such a erse and multi-faceted part of creation.In recent weeks, many have tried to understand why the world finds itself on the potential tipping point of another large-scale war.In part, it is to do with identity – a simplication, I know – and a greed for power, land and wealth.Doomsters will shake their heads and wring their hands in despair, offering little hope.Politicians will talk and negotiate and may God bless them as they do!What will you do Your response will reflect something of your identity.Will you identy with a world-wide movement and pray for the well-being of the world

title: bowlers at twos and threes in the clubhouse
story: Members have been warming up for the outdoor season with a iety of carpet bowls competitions in the comfort of their own clubhouse.On February  the first winter competition was held for the Archie Morans Triples Cup and this was won by Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard.On Saturday the final of the Gilchrist Joiners sponsored Open Pairs was contested and after a competitive three nights two father-and-son pairings progressed to vie for the title.The pairings of Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.The final was closely contested with Jimmy and Craig coming out winners.Organisers congratulated Jimmy and Craig who proved worthy winners and thanked everyone who took part over the week along with new sponsor Gilchrist Joiners.Pic caps: Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard lted the Archie Morans Triples Cup.

title: photograph of the week march 11 2022 2
story: Since the beginning of lockdown Jane has been going out and about with her Galaxy Tablet collecting scenic shots from all over the island. What#s more there are no filters or any tampering whatsoever in her photographs.Just the natural beauty of the West Coast.

title: dogged display on the dunaverty course
story: In the first group out Katharine Hardman played a steady game, despite an unaccompanied dog joining the group on the th green and temporarily pinching her ball.Even with the best endeavours of the dog to disrupt the next couple of holes and increasing wind, Katharine carded a respectable and took the lead.The second group also had to contend with the dog for a couple of holes but this did not deter Eleanor Hawkins who also matched Katharine#s score, but as she had a better inward half took first place.Result: , Eleanor Hawkins #  , Katharine Hardman # , Katie Cappello # .

title: from our files friday march 18
story: Friday March  Gigha was alive yesterday, Thursday, as people travelled to join in the celebrations for its th anniversary of community ownership.Campbeltown Junior Pipe Band piped the children from the local primary school down the main road to the hotel to emphasise the change in the number of children on the island.The children donned their new unorms to mark the occasion, carrying the Gigha flag.Fundraising has been ongoing over a period of time to raise cash towards the celebrations.To date more than £, has been raised, and events have included a race night, celebrations at New Year, and a quiz night.Last night islanders gathered for the ceilidh to bring the celebrations to a close.TWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOFriday March  Argyll’s newest nursing home was officially opened in Campbeltown.The £, Kintyre Nursing Home, which is situated in Hall Street overlooking Campbeltown Loch, was formally opened by Councillor George McMillan.Speaking during the opening of the new home, Mr McMillan said thatthe care in the home was as good as the building itself, no one would have anything to worry about.He went on to explain that getting the home build have not always been an easy task.‘There were some dficulties about the site because of the ground conditions but there were also other problems with the planners about this site because it’s a very prominent site and it’s next door to some very fine buildings on the left-hand side.‘It was a problem getting the plan is to agree to the ious shapes and types of materials that were to be used, but we overcame all these things and got the go-ahead.’FIFTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Popular local turf accountant, Mr Hugh McKellar, has won a holiday for two in Majorca in a raffle organised by Tarbert Football Club.Mr McKellar did not even know he had won the prize. For he threw away the tickets he had bought, thinking that the dance at which the winning ticket was to be drawn had been held.But, unbeknown to him, the fuel crisis meant that thewas postponed for a week.When told he had won the prize, Mr McKellar was flabbergasted.‘It was the biggest surprise of my le. And I’ve had a few,’ he told a Courier man later.Mr McKellar and his we, Christine, both bought tickets. They are still arguing over who won the prize!Mr and Mrs McKellar live with their family at  Ralston Road Campbeltown.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Refloated by Campbeltown LeboatAfter the tow-rope had parted in one attempt, the crew of the Campbeltown leboat, City of Glasgow were lucky in the third venture, when, on a two-and-a-half hour ebb tide, they pulled off the  tons Glasgow coaster Saint Kentigern, which had run aground, bow on, on a ledge of rock on the notorious Paterson’s reef, off the island of Sanda, Mull of Kintyre, in dense fog, on Monday night.The leboat put to see at : pm in response to news from Mr John Macintyre, Lady Mary Row, a member of the leboat crew, who, listening on the short wave, picked up a radio message from the distressed coaster that she was in dficulties and required leboat assistance.The fog had come down suddenly in the late evening and conditions were very thick when the leboat nosed out of Campbeltown Loch and around Davaar.There was a slight breeze and the sea was almost comparatively calm.Standing by, just over six cables away from the coaster, was the Ardchattan of  tons, also belonging to Mrs J and a Gardner and Company,  Clyde Street, Glasgow.Near at hand was the Burns-Laird cargo steamer, Lairdsdale, which had erted course while en-route to Londonderry, to stand-by. Also standing by was the steamer Brora, which was bund for Belfast.The conditions were so bad from the point of view of visibility that the leboat had to receive bearings from the Brora and other ships by means of the Aldis signal lamps while ships’ searchlights assisted them in getting into position. For a time the ships could only see each other on the radar screen.Coxswain Duncan Newlands, who knows this dreaded part of the estuary like the back of his hand, edged his leboat in astern of the coaster and proceeded to begin operations, but at .am came this dramatic message over the leboat’s radio: ‘Arrived alongside casualty at .hours got rope aboard and commenced towing at . hours.‘Rope now parted. Returning alongside St Kentigern for further instructions.’There was a lull in the activities while the leboat resumed its operations. They tried again- without success.Then came the news at . hours – ‘St Kentigern Refloated.’The leboat has succeeded in its third attempt, against odds.The St Kentigern then proceeded to Campbeltown under her own power, while the leboat escorted her, but first it took in tow the coaster’s own leboat, which it had earlier lowered over the port side in case of an emergency.The Ardchattern also accompanied the Saint Kentigern to Campbeltown.Meantime, the two remaining ships, Lairdsdale and Brora, seeing their attendance was no longer required, sent a parting signal of good-luck to the coaster and continued on their respective passages to towards the Irish Coast.

title: leader march 11 2022 2
story: So the Scottish Government remains adamant in its decision to ban creelers from the Clyde for the next two months or so.We#re not talking North Sea trawlers here that can go where in the interim. We#re talking about small family businesses whose livelihoods depend on them setting their creels in the Clyde.Many have invested heavily in their boats and equipment and have no other options available to them but to sit it out.Many employees of Dawnfresh Seafoods were brought to their knees recently after being denied a week#s wages. Our creel fishermen are having to survive  weeks.Financial compensation is a must and government ministers should now make it a priority to offer this. Before irreversible harm is done.Much has already been said about the rallying of our community to come to the aid of the people fleeing their homes in war-torn Ukraine.But we will keep on saying it.This week it was the efforts from our youngest inhabitants that shone through. From collecting donations to making, drawing and writing messages of hope to their European peers.Keep up the good work, everyone.

title: letters march 11 2022 2
story: With some fishermen enduring three weeks of no income and a further eight weeks until the current ban on fishing in the Clyde Recovery Box comes to an end, it was fantastic to see that Argyll and Bute MSP Jenni Minto has lobbied the Minister for Rural Affairs Mairi Gougeon to get financial assistance to help the fishers through this dficult time.Not surprisingly, the Scottish Government have still refused any assistance.At a meeting of the Rural Affairs, Island and Natural Environment Committee on Wednesday March  a vote was taken on whether to annul the ban on fishing in the recovery box.Sadly the MSP for Argyll and Bute decided to look after her own pay packet, political career and tow the line with her Nationalist colleagues to support the ban on fishing in the area.This caused fellow committee member Scottish Conservative Rachel Hamilton to suggest backbenchers, with reference to Ms Minto, are #spineless#.Having deserted the local fishermen, their families and supporting businesses Ms Minto has shown yet another example of Nationalist MSPs being afraid to rock the boat in Holyrood.The Scottish Government has banned creel fishing in parts of the Clyde as part of a plan to protect cod.It was pointed out to our MSP Jenny Minto that:.    The bodies campaigning for this ban did NOT want or need creel fishermen included for the protection of baby cod..    The scientic advice was modied to exclude creel fishing. Baby young cod are not caught in prawn creels. The scientists at the Rural Affairs Committee meeting on March  said that there was zero evidence for creels to be included in the ban, and that the previous evidence cited on the Scottish Government website had now been removed.Our MSP represented to the creel fishermen in Campbeltown that she would:.    Seek a relaxation of the ban to enable the creel fishermen to continue to work as per the scientic evidence advice..    Seek compensation for the creel fishermen for almost three months loss of income.However, in the event she VOTED.    To keep the ban in place.    Against compensation.This is absolutely duplicitous. Duplicity#s original meaning in English has to do with a kind of deception in which true feelings or intentions are hidden behind  words or actions.I wouldn’t blame the children of South Sudanthey just gave up.One third are suffering chronic malnutrition. Half are missing school. Millions are displaced. And none of them have ever known anything but war.One of my colleagues there, a -year-old man, tells me he has never seen peace in his letime. But he has seen hope. He has witnessed the hope our colourful bowls full of maize and beans bring to some of the poorest children on earth.Mary’s Meals feeds more than two million children every school day in  of the world’s poorest countries.Our nutritious meals attract little ones into the classroom, where they can gain an education that gives them hope for the future.We are already reaching around , hungry children in South Sudan, and – with the support of your readers – we can serve our le-changing meals in even more schools. Please visit marysmeals.org.uk to find out more about our appeal.The children of South Sudan aren’t giving up. And nor are we. We know that no child on this earth is unreachable.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2
story: As our planet continues its journey around the sun we notice that theIt is not so dark in the morning and the daylight is extending in the evening. In other words, we are leaving winter behind and spring is around the corner.Although winter brings dark days it also has wonderful surprises on clear nights when the stars seem to dance in the sky and with planets making appearances from time to time.However we must focus on spring. That is where we are just now. This isTrusting from previous years we plant seeds in the knowledge that they will probably germinate and grow into plants before too long. It’s all an amazing process as new le forms.Are the churches still living in dark days or are there signs of new le  Alas in so many places it looks like the former with declining membership rolls and constant struggles to keep going. Given the right conditions however, growth is virtually unstoppable. We see that from the way the grass grows week after week.So what are the churches doing to prevent growth  Are they ploughing the same furrow over and over again or are they looking for fresh ways to cultivate interest It’s not easy butwe resist change it’s going to become even harder.Springtime invites us to take a fresh look at things and sharpen up our prospects for the future. We shouldn’t be afraid to look at things afresh.That’s when we discover new ideas. New ideas bring new le. Let’s be positive about the future.

title: susan to the four on the campbeltown carpet
story: The club held its Ladies# Open Singles on Wednesday March  and, after some great knockout bowls, the semi-finals were decided with Susan Gilchrist playing Fiona Middleton and Jean Miller taking on Roberta Lafferty.The final was contested by Jean and Susan, with Susan coming out on top for the fourth year running with only Covid managing to interrupt her winning run.#Well done to all entrants and congratulations to Susan,# said a club spokesperson.The club will open its green officially on Saturday April . All members old and new are welcome to attend.

title: liveargyll invite to bring along a mum for mothers day
story: liveArgyll leisure members can claim a member guest pass online and bring along a loved one for free, to celebrate a happy and healthy Mother#s Day together.The member guest pass allows any liveArgyll leisure member to invite a guest to enjoy a free gym or swim session, or even a fitness class.It should be noted those wishing to go to a fitness class together will need to phone Aqualibrium on   to book in advance.Robert Judge, liveArgyll area operations manager for Kintyre and Islay, said: ‘This Mother#s Day, liveArgyll wants to help you thank the important women in your le and encourage you to spend time together, all while boosting your health and fitness.‘If you’re not a member, there’s still plenty of ways you can join in the fun. We will be running public swimming sessions over the weekend, including our popular Family Fun session – floor raised – on Sunday from .pm to .pm, or you could book yourselves in for one of our fitness classes.#However you decide to celebrate, we wish you a happy Mother#s Day and look forward to seeing you.’Visit liveargyll mothers-day-guest-pass to request your member guest pass.

title: anglers back in action
story: The fishers kicked things off on Saturday with their usual annual opening day competition.Conditions were described as #less than ideal#, with a strong easterly wind, high water levels and bright sunshine.Although there was no overall winner on the day, there will be more competitions and opportunities throughout the season for the anglers to make their mark.

title: jake at the double
story: The early pace was set by Stuart MacBrayne, playing his first competition for some time, with a creditable nett .This was equalled in the very next match by Willie Ralston, who coped well with the conditions but couldn#t match the inward half of Stuart to sit second.The early pace-setters were soon to be joined at the top by young Jake MacMillan as he managed to produce a great run in the last five holes to pip Stuart by the better inward half and take his second title in a row.#Well done to all who played and huge thanks to head greenkeeper Jonathan Barbour and assistant Campbell MacBrayne for turning the course out in immaculate condition for the time of year,# said a club spokesperson.Result:  Jake MacMillan - ,  Stuart MacBrayne - ,  Willie Ralston -,  Lee Mathieson - ,  Stevie Garrett -,  Jim Williamson - .Lowest gross score on the day went to Lee Mathieson with a cracking .

title: blowing away cobwebs on charity westport walk
story: As well as facing a strong breeze, there were many areas of stones and gravel on the shore which challenged the participants during Saturday afternoon#s charity walk.Thankfully, members of Campbeltown Coastguard were in attendance to ensure all walkers# safety.Despite the challenging conditions, there was also welcome sunshine and the #amazing scenery and company# helped most people complete the five-mile walk in one-and-a-half hours.They then tucked in to some well-earned refreshments at Machrihanish Village Hall, including home-baked goods made by members of the Mairi Semple Cancer Fund committee.Argyll Bakeries also donated some baking and sausage rolls which were gratefully received and enjoyed by all.The hall hire was free of charge, a gesture for which the Mairi Semple Cancer Fund committee is very thankful to the Machrihanish Village Hall committee.The final total was still being counted as the Courier went to press but, between entry fees, sponsorships, donations and a raffle, the event raised more than £, which will help the charity to continue financially supporting people from Kintyre affected by cancer.#The committee continues to be amazed by the generosity of the community, raising over £, in one afternoon,# said Jane Millar, the fund#s company secretary.#We were pleased to see so many people participate in the walk and help raise awareness of the fund.#We have a few more fundraising events planned for this year, including a football fun day and a golf competition at Dunaverty, so keep an eye on our Facebook page and local notice boards for posters advertising these events.#

title: campbeltown brass scottish champions 2
story: The band was judged to be the #clear winner# in the second section at last weekend#s Scottish Brass Band Association#s Scottish Regional Championships at Perth Concert Hall, one of the first major competitions to be held since the beginning of the Covid pandemic.The band#s soprano cornet player also won the championship#s best instrumentalist award.This means Campbeltown Brass, which has players as young as , will represent Scotland at the National Brass Band Championships of Great Britain finals at Cheltenham in September and is now eligible for promotion to the first section.Adjudicator John Doyle said the band#s performance on Saturday #had everything#, adding that it was #very simple# but #the devil was in the detail#.Much of the band#s success has been attributed to conductor Stephanie Kennedy – formerly Mitchell – for her dedication to helping the band maintain its high standards.#I am absolutely delighted with the band’s result,# said Mrs Kennedy. #I was so proud of everyone as I could feel the enjoyment coming from all the players when we were on stage.#It was such an overwhelming feeling when we were named the winning band as there has been so much hard work and effort put in by everyone.#Band member Katrina Barr said: #All credit to Stephanie, her level of commitment to Campbeltown Brass is amazing.#She added: #Everyone in the band is really proud of one another, and the work that we put in.#It’s not just one player who makes the band, it really was a team effort on the day, on one of the most challenging stages any of us has ever played.#All bands have faced a particularly challenging couple of years, with Covid restrictions having a huge impact on their ability to practise and perform together.Mrs Kennedy was quick to set up virtual banding early in the pandemic, when performers were not permitted to meet physically. This proved so successful that she was approached by other bands asking for advice on organising their own virtual sessions.When restrictions relaxed, band members were then allowed to meet, providing they maintained a two-metre distance.And although distancing has now been scrapped for some activities including sports, musicians still have to maintain a one-metre distance, even during competitions, adding another level of dficulty and making Campbeltown Brass#s success even more impressive.The band is now gearing up for a busy year of fundraising to raise the estimated £, required for the trip to Cheltenham. With a round-trip of almost , miles, Campbeltown Brass will be the furthest travelled band at the competition.Keep an eye out for more information on the upcoming events, including a concert, a raffle, a silent disco and ious pancake teas and coffee mornings.

title: district news march 25 2022
story: Some of West Kintyre#s best plants, baking and art was proudly displayed at Whitehouse, Clachan, Largieside and Bellochantuy Scottish Women#s Institutes# annual joint bulb show.Hosted by Whitehouse SWI, this year#s event was held at Whitehouse Village Hall on Wednesday March .The show consists of three main sections: bulbs, plants and floral art, which had  entries arts and handcrafts, which had  entries baking and preserves, which had  entries, plus sundries.A vast array of plants and flowers made for a wonderful display, with an accompanying heady perfume from the hyacinths.The high degree of skills, expertise and imagination in the arts and handcrafts section showed off the many creative talents of institute members.In the baking section, the most popular competitions were the soda bread and the cherry cake, while the marzipan fruits, in the sundries class, were exquisitely made and very realistic in appearance.The show was judged by Jen Ronald, Margaret Bakes and Mary Cameron, three SWI members from the Southend institute.The inidual winners of each section were: Floral Cup: Adrienne Bradley, Largieside SWI Baking Cup: Zoe Weir, Clachan SWI Liz Dale Trophy for Arts and Crafts: Linda Bryce, Bellochantuy SWI.The MacGregor-Smith Trophy for best exhibit in show was awarded to Agnes Sillars of Whitehouse SWI, for the impressive amaryllis she had grown and nurtured.The overall winning institute with the most total points was Clachan SWI. The inidual entrant with most points was Zoe Weir of Clachan SWI.The judges gave high praise for the work and effort put into all the show entries and said they enjoyed judging and congratulated competitors for making it a wonderful show.#All who attended the show commented that it had been a great success and an enjoyable social event,# said an event spokesperson.#It was an opportunity to show the community that the Rural – as it was once known – is fun and that members are interested in a iety of skills, making new friends and meeting up with ‘old’ friends!#

title: from our files march 11 2022 2
story: Work will begin next week on Campbeltown’s long-awaited all-weather sports pitch.The final confirmation of the project at Kinloch Green next to Aqualibrium has beenSpecialist contractors AP Thompson based in Oxfordshire will move its workers in onAfter  years of campaigning, the start of the work would be a proud moment forHe added: ‘After a dignied campaign by the community over the last  years, it’s‘We look forward to working with the council to maximise use for our local sportsLast weekend’s Pupils game was called off, and club secretary Campbell RobertsonHe said: ‘At the moment the boys have to travel up to Tarbert over winter to train.Alex McKinven, chairman of the Campbeltown Community Football Group, said:‘It’s going to give kids an opportunity to play the game at any time of day, on a properTWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOThe problem of looking for that more unusual, yet special, gt could be a thing of theCampbeltown Pottery, based at Hazelburn Business Park, not only sells genuineCampbeltown Pottery is owned and run by a potter with more than  years’ experience in the trade. Simon Rochford moved to the town earlier this year after working in the pottery on Mull for over a decade.After deciding to set up business on his own and scouring Scotland for the idealSince arriving in the town, Simon has been busy producing items for sale ready forTo mark the launch of his sophisticated designs, much of which are based on themesSimon’s work will also be on sale in the Oystercatcher after the launch along withAlternatively for a chance to see Simon’s beautul designs, the pottery workshop atFIFTY YEARS AGOA coach load of Campbeltown Orangemen from LOL district number  joined theAn estimated , marchers including  bands took part in the parade fromThe Campbeltown contingent received a special welcome and was thanked for making the long journey.Many members were pleased to meet up with a Campbeltonian who has gone to theMrs Ranachan, who has visited ‘the wee toon’ with city deputations in past years, is aSEVENTY YEARS AGOMr Dugald Semple gave a lantern lecture on ‘With Camp, Caravan and Camera’ lastThere was a large attendance of members and visitors from other districts. Mr CK Brown of Ifferdale presided.Before showing his slides, Mr Semple spoke about his open-air experiences in a bellThousands of people came to see the supposed hermit, who at that time was working as a draughtsman in an engineering shop.He later moved to Bridge of Weir where he lived in a caravan for nine years, givingAfterwards he went to London to lecture on food economy at the Imperial Exhibitions in the People’s Palace.Returning to Kilmacolm he acted as lecturer to the Scottish Food League, and alsoMr Semple told also about his ious experiences as a land worker at his hill croftOver  beautul slides were shown on the screen, depicting camp le, a trip to theMr R Lamont MA proposed a hearty vote of thanks to the lecturer and also to Mr JR

title: leader march 25 2022
story: With Campbeltown Brass#s continued success in competitions throughout many years, it would be easy to take it for granted.But it is thanks to nothing but an incredible amount of hard work and dedication that it was voted the best band in the second section – just two shy of the championship section – at last weekend#s Scottish Brass Band Association’s Scottish Regional Championships.Adjudicators described Campbeltown Brass as the #clear winner# an amazing achievement made even more spectacular given the band has players as young as , the youngest performing musicians in the entire section.It takes a lot of dedication to attend weekly practices at the best of times but for the band#s members to maintain their high performance level despite all the challenges of the Covid pandemic, is outstanding.We should be so proud that the best second section band in Scotland bears the name Campbeltown, so let#s get behind the band and support its fundraising efforts ahead of its trip to the National Brass Band Championships of Great Britain finals at Cheltenham in September.

title: letters march 11 2022 2 2
story: I would like to take this opportunity to clary my position regarding the forthcoming council election.After  years in office, my position has somewhat changed, as was well documented in the Campbeltown Courier in October .Despite myself and numerous constituents querying the decision taken, a satisfactory explanation has still not been provided.As readers will know, I always stand up for my local community at every turn and put South Kintyre first, rather than toeing the party line, when council decisions are made.I am of the opinion that this is the reason for the decision that was taken last year. I fully believe that local elections should not be about party politics and I have not and will not ever be a puppet for any political party.I am therefore standing at this election as an independent candidate.I have worked tirelessly to support and advocate for the community of South Kintyre over the last  years.I would like to thank everyone who has supported me in the past and respectfully request that you consider voting for me on May  so that I may have the opportunity to continue to represent you to the very best of my ability.Please note, due to current widespread and high level of Covid- affecting our community, I have taken the decision not to carry out door-to-door canvassing in the upcoming election.I have canvassed door-to-door in every election since , however, on this occasion, I feel it would be irresponsible to do so given the current situation.As always, please feel free to contact me should you wish any further information. Email: Donald.kelly@argyll-bute.gov.uk. Mobile:  .In the council elections on May  I will be seeking re-election to the council as your independent candidate for the Kintyre and the Islands ward.It is my firm belief that party politics at local level should not be important. What is important is having a strong local councillor who will help out his constituents and work day-in and day-out for our local area.With your support, I hope to continue to represent the Kintyre and the Islands ward.I am an Islay resident and have lived there my whole le with my family, many of whom work locally in the NHS and in farming, crofting, fishing and distillery sectors.I will always put my local constituents first, above any political party or special interest group. I have spent the past five years working for every corner of the Kintyre and the Islands ward.If you have a problem that you need help with, no matterit#s a big or small issue, then please don#t hesitate to contact me.I give the people of the Kintyre and the Islands ward my promise that I will work day-in and day-out for you.

title: pupils u13s in football action
story: Campbeltown Pupils stravelled to Clydebank to play BSC Glasgowon Sunday March , looking to follow-up on their draw with Busby the previous week.After a promising start, the Pupils found themselves - down at half-time, through a combination of poor defending, and also some good play from the BSC attackers.The young Campbeltown team rallied in the second half, and with a much better all-round performance, capped off with goals from Ryan Johnston and Ben Cunningham.Finnart #s The young Pupils# second away game in a row saw them travel on Sunday to play league leaders Finnart.The first  minutes saw the Pupils put in one of their best performances of the season, competing in every position, and they were rewarded midway through the half with a brilliant -yard strike from Ryan Johnston that found the top corner.The pace and strength of the league leaders# attackers started to cause problems, however, and two quick-fire goals gave Finnart the lead.The crucial goal came with the last kick of the half, with slack defending from the Pupils allowing Finnart to go into the break - ahead.The second half was a very even affair. The Pupils were unlucky to see a free kick from Johnston go wide, and an effort from Jack Green slip just by the post, but it was Finnart who put the game beyond reach with two goals in the last  minutes – goals that were very much preventable from the Pupils# perspective.This Sunday, the s will play a home match against BSC Glasgow , the first of three home games in a row.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2 2
story: If I had to ask you the question #are you tired # How would you answer We live in a culture that is becoming preoccupied with busy-ness and our daysDespite the noticeable signs of struggle in trying to keep up with the pace ofI have taken immense strength and support from two verses in scripture thatPsalm  v  says: Be still and know that I am God.Rest can be found when we stop and take time out of our busy schedules andMatthew  v  says: Come to me all who are weary and heavy laden and IJesus invites us to find rest in Him because He knows our human tiredness. He Himself experienced exhaustion, loneliness, weariness, anxiety, and stress.Are you perhaps feeling weary, burdened, tired, and run down  I would encourage you in the busy-ness of le to seek rest in the presence of God.

title: way to work is just the job for employers and candidates
story: .Jobcentre Plus has a long and successful track record of matching quality employers with quality candidates. Now, many highly-skilled people have found themselves unemployed for the first time, and are considering new roles in new sectors. Jobcentre Plus can quickly put companies in touch with candidates who can make a real dference to their businesses.We talk to employers and employees about how they have benefited from working with Jobcentre Plus.‘Working with Jobcentre Plus is a no brainer’: Jordan, Contracts Manager, Elite Scaffolding, YeovilElite Scaffolding – a family-owned business that is part of the Denholm Group, reached out to Jobcentre Plus in a bid to reach younger potential employees looking for an apprenticeship.#We initially approached the jobcentre, simply for advice and to askthey could place an ad on their system. We did not expect the extremely positive and proactive response we received from the jobcentre. The team was very helpful,# said Jordan.The support Elite got from the jobcentre was invaluable in streamlining and accelerating its recruitment process which would take up to five weeks.#Now, the jobcentre advertises our vacancies via a sector-based work academy.#Candidates attend a two-week course at Weston College, Yeovil, to gain their Scaffolding Operative Training Scheme and Health  Safety Certications, as well as to prepare for an interview. Now when we interview candidates, they already have a scaffold labourer trainee card and the basic knowledge and understanding of the scaffolding industry. What’s more, all this support via the jobcentre comes without the additional fees of private agencies.#Out of seven candidates, six were offered jobs and five have remained with Elite which has  qualied operatives.#The process was seamless and effective, providing quality candidates who were keen to learn.#Working with the jobcentre is a no brainer! As well as alleviating the burden of interviews that don’t progress into jobs, the savings in cost and time to get candidates suitably qualied are a bonus. It takes the pressure off our own resources and provides top quality candidates in the process.#‘Delighted’: Simon, Employer Adviser, Yeovil JobCentreSimon joined the Department of Work and Pensions as a work coach two years ago after  years in sales and marketing in the private sector. He became an employer adviser a year ago.Once approached by Elite Scaffolding, also based in Yeovil, he set up a meeting with one of its office managers and worked out a bespoke recruitment package.As part of the programme, he contacted the local Weston College and together they “built” the course content.#I arranged for the employer’s contracts manager to present to the class through an online  so they could explain what the business could offer them and what they we were looking for.#At the end of the two-week course, six candidates were offered a place on the apprenticeship scheme at a starting salary of £,.#Elite had exhausted all other channels to recruit and were delighted with the outcome#, he said.Moreover Elite referred other local employers to the jobcentre and Simon is running another sector-based work academy with a local roofing company.#If you’re looking to fill a vacancy, Jobcentre Plus can offer you a named employer adviser in your local jobcentre that knows the local geography for both employers and those looking for work.#The jobcentre has an incredible pool of talent. One of my Elite Scaffolders said it’s not just about finding me a job but changing my le…You certainly can’t ask for better than that.#Simon, Employer Advisor‘Welcome’: Samuel, JD Sports Apprentice, RochdaleSamuel’s career got off to a flying start with a six-month placement through Jobcentre Plus at JD Sports.“I left college in January . I didn’t finish my A-levels because I wanted a change. I knew I would be good in a computer-based job because it’s something that I’ve gravitated towards.“I saw JD Sports was advertising and I thought I’d go for it because it was an administration role in a big company. Everything went through really quickly.#Continued the  year-old: “My team at JD were great from day one. They made me feel welcome and supported me. I spent six months on the placement and I got paid, too. It’s a proper job which was exactly what I needed. Day to day, I’d look after anything from HR queries and issuing contracts to payroll and pension questions. It gave me a whole picture of what it’s like to work in HR and I’ve been doing it ever since.“After six months, there was the option to stay on and I’m now doing an apprenticeship with JD. Once I’d finished with the placement I got started on a qualication – CIPD level three in HR support. It was another perfect step for me and I’ve now been there for a year. Now I’m learning about dferent parts of HR, building on what I was doing on the placement. Jobcentre Plus helped me and now I’ll just keep going.”Samuel, ApprenticeJobseeker  Right now, a Jobcentre Plus work coach is ready to match you to your next job* – find out more at gov.uk way to work gdpr_consentltd " https:jobhelp.campaign.gov.uk way-to-work Employer  Is your business recruiting  With thousands of quality candidates gdpr_consentltd "Jobcentre Plus  can help fill your vacancies now*.*Eligibility criteria apply

title: help put argyll and bute on the platinum jubilee map
story: Events of all types marking the platinum jubilee are being recorded on a nationwide interactive map to showcase all the dferent celebrations happening across the country.There are ious ways that local groups and organisations can get involved – and there’s still time to start planning.Celebrations including street parties, #big jubilee lunches#, beacon lighting and many more can be registered on the interactive map.There have also been lots of other celebratory competitions, from creating a special platinum jubilee pudding recipe to knitting toy corgis.There’s an important Argyll and Bute link to one of the most prestigious competitions, which will feature in celebrations all over the Commonwealth.Inveraray’s world champion pipe major Stuart Liddell is literally playing his part in putting Argyll and Bute on the platinum jubilee map after his bagpipe tune, Diu Regnare, was the winning entry in a contest to compose a special melody for the Queen.Diu Regnare – Latin for #long to reign# – will be played by pipers all over the Commonwealth at sunset on June , with Stuart planning to play at Inveraray Bridge.#I have heard of a number of local groups who are putting celebratory plans in place for platinum jubilee events,# said Jane MacLeod, the Lord-Lieutenant of Argyll and Bute.#I’m sure Argyll and Bute will mark this unique and historic occasion in its usual enthusiastic style and full of the community spirit that the area is famous for.#I would encourage anyone who is planning a celebration event to make sure they register online – we can all make sure that Argyll and Bute has the place it deserves on the celebrations map.#Register your event, and find out more, at platinumjubilee.gov.uk get-involved-with-the-platinum-jubileeAnd anyone who creates a platinum pudding recipe, bakes a jubilee celebration cake or knits a corgi is being asked to email photographs to lord-lieutenant@argyll-bute.gov.uk so they can be featured on the Argyll and Bute Lieutenancy Instagram feed.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: zans-wildlife-diary-owls-stunning-return
story: Two winters have passed and I have not seen the owls since. I had slowly started to think that it was a once-in-a-letime opportunity until fortune smiled upon me one more time.About two weeks ago, I had a busy day at work. To recharge my batteries, I decided to go on a quick walk with the camera.Short-eared owl. Image: Zan BlaszczykAs soon as I left the house, the weather changed its course and the sky was shortly covered by nimbus clouds. Normally I wouldhome and grab my raincoat, but I did not want to waste time.When I arrived at the local reserve, the first rain droplets fell on the ground and the place became deserted. I took a wander and soon spotted a familiar flight pattern above the marshes. Upon checking through my camera, I confirmed it was a short-eared owl.The bird was flying low and patrolling the ground for voles. It even managed to catch one but it was tricky to get a good-quality photo due to the distance between us. The bird flew past me on a couple of occasions but the weather was getting worse with every minute so I headed back home. The word about the owl must have spread, as when I ed two days later, I met other fellow photographers looking for the stunning bird.I ed to the same spot as previously and sat on a rock and waited patiently. Shortly afterwards, a graceful owl with a wingspan of around cm appeared on the horizon. Without changing my position, I started following the bird with the camera. Imagine my surprise when the owl flew over me and looked straight at the camera! I silently shouted to myself: “Wow!”As soon as the owl flew behind me, I slowly turned back and spotted the second bird. Both owls were flying towards each other and, as they met halfway, they started their ‘sky dance’.The male began to rise in the sky whilst performing a combination of dynamic wing beats and gliding down, then rising again. He also made several squeaky calls accompanied by dynamic wing claps at high speeds! After repeating the whole sequence a few times, he started falling from the sky. The female joined in and they started going at each other: the birds were e-bombing one another and attacking with their talons. That aerial display lasted for about  minutes until the birds separated. What a scene it was!Courtship behaviour is spectacular for this species: often, two birds will lock their talons and, whilst holding onto each other, they will start tumbling nearly to the ground before letting go.I encourage everyone who has a chance to observe this behaviour, as this is a ‘must’ in the birding world. It is worth remembering, though, that this species is sensitive to disturbance and their numbers are considered declining during the past two decades. It is crucial not to approach the owls or their nesting site. For your observation, I would recommend choosing one spot and remaining there. This way, you have a chance to show them that you are no threat to them and hopefully the owls will get used to your presence. I prefer this technique rather than hiding as, considering owls’ excellent eyesight, it is almost impossible to stay unnoticed. By waiting at the same position, we can also eliminate another factor, which is chasing off their prey: as we walk, the ground shakes under our feet and small mammals, such as mice or voles which the owls feed on, will disappear. Short-eared owls like marshy and boggy places, so it is important not to walk over the rich habitat but use paths.www.zanslenswww.facebook zanslenswww zans_lensIf you have owls living in your backyard or would like me to photograph and feature wildle from your area, please get in touch!

title: brunton-musselburgh-children-star-bugsy-malone
story: Youth acting group Drama Mill auditioned  children for the show, and now has a cast of  children from North Berwick, Aberlady, Gullane, Cockenzie and Haddington, aged from eight to .Linda Kearsley Ross, Drama Mill director, said that the performance – the group’s first foray into musical theatre – was “ambitious” but that the children had loved taking on the roles of s New York gangsters.County children to star in Bugsy MaloneShe added: “Bugsy Malone was our first choice of play.“Drama facilitators Claudia Overton and Stephanie Wynne and I have all taken part in productions when we were at school and have fond memories of performing this play.“It’s ambitious to do it with such a young castbut our fabulous talented group have risen to the task.“This is the first time we have performed at The Brunton and we are so excited to give our youngsters the opportunity to perform on a professional stage.”The cast will perform the famous musical numbers accompanied by a live nine-piece band, whose members are all volunteering their time and talent.Drama faclitator Stephanie Wynne coaches the young Bugsy Malone castAnd the production will emulate the original  film, starring Jodie Foster, by using splurge guns and foam pies.Linda said: “There is something really fun about playing gangsters and molls, and using splurge to take people down rather than bullets.“Some people criticised that the ending is really abrupt, i.e. that they all become friends and sing a song, but I don’t think children question the ending – they believe bad people can become good people and that, as the words say, ‘ you give a little love then it all comes back to you’.”Tickets can be bought via    or thebrunton en-GB shows bugsy%malone events - Bugsy Malone is on at The Brunton on March  .

title: pear-tree-nursery-gets-approval-changes-west-road-premises
story: The Pear Tree Nursery, on Haddington’s West Road, was given approval for advertisements at the front of the Category B listed building.The business was also given the green light to create a toilet which could be accessed at the rear of the building.The Architectural Heritage Society of Scotland claimed the height and positioning of the signage meant it “visually intrudes on the main façade of the listed building and the wider conservation area”.The group also felt the works had “no architectural merit and are not in keeping with the listed building”.However, East Lothian Council’s planning department granted permission with the condition that the advertising consent expires in March .

title: chance-boost-fitness-levels-couch-5k
story: The initiative starts on Wednesday, April , with a gentle introduction by trained jog leaders.It is aimed at people who want to try running for the first time, others who might want to take it up again after injury or illness, or those who simply want to get more exercise.Charles Stable, the club’s vice-chairman, said: “The programme has been made possible with the support of East Lothian Sports Hub, who have assisted greatly with the funding for training our jog leaders.”He added: “Many of the runners who start with the Couch to k programme gain confidence to keep on running and take on and achieve many personal running challenges.“The -week course culminated in completing a local parkrun supported by members of Musselburgh and District Athletics Club.”A drop-in information event will be held at Fisherrow Yacht Club in New Street, Musselburgh, on Wednesday, March , when anyone interested in getting involved can meet the jog leaders from .pm to .pm.For more information, visit musselburghac jogscotland-musselburgh

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-march-24-28-1997-1972-1922
story: ‘BOSNIANS say thank you for help’, reported the East Lothian Courier on March , .A group of Bosnians , who found safety in East Lothian after escaping the civil war in the former Yugoslavia, have shown their appreciation of the man who brought them to Scotland and helped them build a new le.Eddie Carmichael, formerly of the Bosnian Project Team, was presented with an engraved wrist watch as a ‘thank you’ for his help, from a group of Bosnians living in Haddington and Dunbar.Jasmin Kilic, one of those forced to leave the country, spoke of his gratitude to Mr Carmichael.“We came to Scotland from Croatia in March  and Eddie was our co-ordinator and helped us find homes, schools and also brought together a lot of families that had been split up by the war,” he said....and  years ago‘COUNCIL objects to strip shows in pubs’ was a headline in the East Lothian Courier of March , .An objection to striptease shows being held in licensed premises was made by Cockenzie and Port Seton Town Council to East Lothian Licensing Court on Tuesday.In a letter to the court, the Town Clerk, Mr T. Walker said: “I have been instructed by my Council to write objecting to the striptease show which my Council understand was held recently in the Port Seton Hotel.“It is understood this was a private show and that admittance was by ticket only. Nevertheless my Council are very strongly of the opinion that this is not the type of show which should be held on licensed premises and I have been asked to request the court to consider this matter when dealing with the renewal of the certicate for the hotel.”...and  years agoA DISTURBANCE by a soldier in East Linton was described by The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .On Monday, in Haddington Sherf Court, James Michael Collins, private in the H.L.I., East Fortune, pleaded guilty to having, on Saturday, committed a breach of the peace at the Red Lion Hotel, East Linton, and on the public road, and subsequently broken a pane of glass in a window in the police station.It was stated that the accused and another soldier had been refused a drink at the hotel, owing to their intoxicated condition.They ed, and, on again being refused, committed a disturbance.

title: 150k-funding-donated-help-over-50s-keep-active
story: Shine Public Health has been awarded £, of UK Research and Innovationfunding as part of the Healthy Ageing Challenge.The project is Shine’s first large-scale trial, supporting over-s across East Lothian.The Haddington-based social enterprise company aims to connect everyone with physical activities they will enjoy and keep enjoying.The company has developed an app, Shine, that is designed to help community-based health campaigns increase levels of physical activity, improving quality of le and drastically reducing long-term healthcare costs.Dr Joanna Smail, GP partner at Tranent Medical Practice, backed the social enterprise’s aims.She said: “We know first-hand that increasingly large sums of money are being spent on expensive drugs to treat conditions which could be prevented and managed with lestyle change.“As a GP, I wholeheartedly support Shine in their mission to increase physical activity provision, getting people more active and transforming lives.”Physical inactivity is one of the leading causes of premature death.Small increases in activity, particularly for older people, can help prevent and manage long-term conditions.Shine aims to help people get more active, in a way that is right for them, removing barriers to participation, supporting changes in behaviour and encouraging healthy habits.The -month project got under way this month and will involve testing the app with a range of activity providers and classes for over-s across East Lothian.Research and evaluation carried out by the University of Stirling will test Shine’s ability to deliver lasting behavioural change.Councillor John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian, said: “Shine provides a fantastic opportunity for local groups to be rewarded for the incredible support and encouragement they provide, improving the health and wellbeing of our community.”Shine welcomes any activity provider within East Lothian to sign up.They will receive a share of £,, plus help to improve their online promotion and hopefully an increase in membership.

title: watch-line-duty-reunion-martin-compston-jed-mercurio-vicky-mcclure-adrian-dunbar
story: ACs Steve Arnott, Kate Fleming and Ted Hastings are experts in handling confidential information ... but let a few secrets leak out as they were grilled in aid of a good cause.Actors Martin Compston, Vicky McClure and Adrian Dunbar were on stage with the shows creator Jed Mercurio and host Gordon Smart for all the big questions.To watch the show click HERE - but you will have to be a subscriber. To subscribe - and receive a £ MS voucheryou take an annual subscription - please click HERE!Highlights included the trio recreating their viral TikTok dance, a raucous sing-song led by Dunbar and McClure revealing which female co-star she would have "happily kissed".While plenty of laughs were shared, the big question was put to the team too... is the case being built for a seventh season And, of course, the stars couldnt be ed to freedom without delivering a catchphrase or too first."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "An audience with AC  u promo","description": title: travelodge-ranks-top-10-uk-landmarks-visit-spring---see
story: The hotel chain has been gearing up for the Easter break by slashing the prices of its rooms and rounding up the best spots you can visit on your Spring staycation."When we think of places wed love to visit in our letime, our mind often wanders to faraway places across the globe. Its easy to forget that we have an abundance of incredible landmarks right here in the UK," Travelodge said.The company added: "We have handpicked a selection that we think should be on your list to visit this spring, from castles to cathedrals and everything in between!"York Minster. Credit: PA Here are the top ten UK landmarks that should be on your to-visit list this Spring, according to Travelodge.Shop the best deals to stay nearby these popular tourist spots this year via the Travelodge website.: TripAdvisor reveals the top British Spring destinations : Tripadvisor reveals best international destinations for Spring - See the top Blackpool Tower. Credit: PA It is now easier than ever to plan your ultimate Easter staycation without blowing the budget.The hotel chain has slashed the price of , rooms across its  locations.You can access the £ room deal now on stays between Friday, April  and Sunday, April , .The offer is subject to some terms and conditions including that all rates are subject to availability at the time of booking.It may also not be available at every hotel, every night.If youre booking a stay for a family of four  a £ room works out at just £ per person.A night away is already working out cheaper than a trip to your local cinema and could open doors to a spot youve not explored together before.See all the terms and conditions and book your bargain stay via the Travelodge website.

title: aldi-lidl-middle-aisles-sunday-march-27
story: Whether it’s Aldi’s Specialbuys or Lidl’s Middle of Lidl, the latest offers are always worth checking out and there are some fantastic buys from Sunday, March .Lets take a look at some of the items you can buy this weekend.This Sunday, you’ll find a iety of items amongst Aldi’s Specialbuys including cycling and golf gear as well as garden furniture.Soyou’re looking to upgrade your sports attire, equipment or garden, now you can with Aldi." alt"East Lothian Courier: Gardenline  Piece Furniture Set " class"editor-image"Gardenline  Piece Furniture SetTake some time out and relax with this Gardenline  Piece Furniture Set.For £., this set comes with a dining table, four chairs and a parasol so your garden will be summer ready.This is an online exclusive so it won’t be available in stores. You can add it to your online shopping basket via the Aldi website here." alt"East Lothian Courier: Anthracite  Grey Rattan Bistro Set " class"editor-image"Anthracite  Grey Rattan Bistro SetEnjoy the warmer months in the comfort of your own garden with this Anthracite  Grey Rattan Bistro Set.You’ll get a table, two chairs and two cushions for £. and it’s also available in Grey  Cream and Grey  Anthracite.You can buy it via the Aldi website here." alt"East Lothian Courier: Clubs   Wheel Golf Trolley Set " class"editor-image"Clubs   Wheel Golf Trolley SetTreat yourself or the golf lover in your le to this Clubs   Wheel Golf Trolley Set.The set comes complete with eight golf clubs and one golf trolley with three wheels.It’s available online only for £. via the Aldi website." alt"East Lothian Courier: Bike Essentials Accessory Pack " class"editor-image"Bike Essentials Accessory PackUpgrade your cycling equipment with this Bike Essentials Accessory Pack.This accessory pack will help you get yourself prepared for a cycling trip as it comes with a bike pump, a bottle and bottle cage, two USB bike lights which are rechargeable and a cable lock.For just £., this set could be yours via the Aldi website.
