title: bobby retires after 40 years keeping the water flowing
story: A water worker has been commended for his four decades of public service.The -year-old from Lerwick said the time had gone by ldquolike a flash.ldquoIrsquove worked all over Shetland, from Fair Isle to Unst but I really enjoyed working in Lerwick, working in the town, he added.ldquoTrying to find the bursts, digging them up and repairing them, that was very, very satisfying.Mr Fullerton worked in water operations from - and spent the last  years in the sampling team.Over the years he has dealt with ldquolots of bursts in strange places including getting ldquoabsolutely soaked and contending with a  foot jet of water in the centre of Lerwick.A keen motorcyclist, Mr Fullerton said he was now looking forward to having more time to spend on le outside work.ldquoIrsquom going to miss the people that you get to work with for a long time, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think there is anyone left from the days that I started which is a strange feeling but it is nice to be part of the team.Water team leader Jim Anderson said Mr Fullerton would be missed by his colleagues.ldquoHis great sense of humour and willingness to help anybody and everybody who knocked on his door for yet another lsquoquick favourrsquo will certainly not be forgotten, he added...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.Scottish Water has said it will be renewing around km of water mains between Bigton and Maywick over the next year. The £.m project will#Drivers have been warned of signicant delays while repairs are carried out to a burst watermain at a busy roundabout. Three-way traffic lights have been#Scottish Water has completed an £, project to upgrade their water treatment works in Unst. The work was delivered by Scottish Water’s in-house capital project#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: electoral contest in south mainland assured
story: An election contest is assured in the South Mainland in May, with five candidates standing for the ward. to stand means voters in the Shetland South ward will be required to choose who will represent them in the next council.Only three candidates came forward for election in , in what was then a three-member ward.Electoral boundary changes have since meant the Shetland South area will be served by four elected members.Independent Mr Peterson will be standing against Shetland Greens candidate Alex Armitage in May#s electoral contest.Earlier this month construction industry expert Stewart Douglas announced he would also be standing.Mr Douglas last stood for council in , when he campaigned for the Shetland Central seat under an SNP ticket.But he is standing as an independent candidate this time round.Retaining the fight for the SNP will be Robbie McGregor, however, who is understood to be standing again for the SNP for the Scottish nationalists.Meanwhile, Allison Duncan is contesting for Shetland South again., the  year-old said there was #unfinished business# he wished to see done.#My main priorities are the Levenwick road refurbishment and the Fair Isle ferry # and close behind that is the water mist suppressant system to enhance safety in all our care homes in Shetland,# he said.Mr Duncan said it was a #severe disappointment# that not enough potential candidates came forward in the South Mainland in .He said standing against four other candidates #will tell meI#ve done a reasonable job, a good job, orI#m no damned use#.#This election will at least give me the answer,# he said.Mr Duncan insisted he would continue as an independent candidate.Askedhe had considered standing for the SNP, he replied: #You must be crazy to stand for that outfit.#Local writer and broadcaster Tom Morton will stand as an official Scottish Labour Party candidate in the Shetland North ward.#I believe the party#s values best represent a viable and valuable future for Shetland,# he said.#Compassion, social justice and fairness are traditional Shetland qualities, and these are the core ideals of the Scottish Labour Party.#And Shetland Central member Moraig Lyall has said she will stand again...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.The chairman of Sandwick Community Council says he will stand in the SIC elections for Shetland South.Stewart Douglas has announced he is standing as a council election candidate in Shetland South.The spectre of “real term cuts” could loom over Shetland Islands Council in the next financial year, following a below-inflation budget allocation from the ScottishShetland Islands Council is #lurching into a crisis#, according to councillor Allison Duncan. title: spaceport overcomes final hurdle to start work on historic 100m project
story: Work can finally begin on Shetlandrsquos poundm space centre after ministers confirmed they had no intention to intervene.The Scottish government told the SIC on Friday that it was able to approve the SaxaVord Spaceport as initially indicated last month.Although the council previously confirmed it was ldquominded to approve the application ndash Scottish ministers had  days to decide whether to ldquocall it in.With that threat no longer looming over the project, work can now get under way.Blasting work had already begun and shipments of stone chips arrived on site ndash but the team had been awaiting the governmentrsquos final go ahead before beginning the major work.Over the next  months the team plans to spend poundm ndash rising to poundm over five years.Despite planning delays, with approval taking almost  months, the first launch is still hoped to take place this year.It is hoped to create around  jobs in Unst and boost the islandrsquos economy by almost poundm a year. It is expected to provide a further  jobs throughout Shetland...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.The global company looking to deliver the UKrsquos first vertical satellite launch has welcomed the approval of spaceport plans ndash saying ldquoall systems are go#.Work on a £m spaceport could start next month after receiving its long-awaited planning approval.The Shetland Space Centre in Unst is changing its name to SaxaVord Spaceport. title: use reserves to create investment bank greens say
story: A new investment bank could be created, using money from the council#s reserves.The idea is being developed by Shetland Greens, who wish to see at least  per cent of reserves invested locally by the end of the next council term.It follows an earlier suggestion from the party that an energy company be launched # also using money from the reserve fund.The party says loans would be made from the Shetland Investment Bank at affordable rates of interest.The aim is to spark the development of community owned renewable energy projects and support small businesses, helping to ersy Shetland#s local economy. The party says larger loans from the bank could also part-finance fixed links to Yell, Unst and Whalsay.The SIC reserve fund and pension fund are together currently valued at well over £bn, with all of this money currently invested on the international stock market.Shetland South candidate Alex Armitage said: #The global economy is in upheaval with conflict and is threatened by climate breakdown.#Many economists are predicting a recession in coming years. We have the opportunity to make more secure investments in Shetland # and that#s exactly what we should be doing with our reserves.#..Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.Shetland has shown overwhelming support for Ukraine, with a pop up shop raising almost £,.Folk should take the time to submit electricity and gas meter readings before the energy price cap rises this Friday st April, urges Shetland MP#Time is running out for would-be candidates thinking of throwing their hats in the ring for election.Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: gallaher trust seeks outside the box ideas
story: THE Gallaher Trust is searching for social enterprises, charities and ‘those who can think outside the box’ to help make a dference to the Ballymena community. The Trust has announced that funding applications for delivery partners have opened for . One of those ‘outside the box’ ideas was the creation of the Northern Ireland Hospitality School, which allowed three local hoteliers to come together under the umbrella of a not-for-profit organisation to create courses and programmes for the Ballymena hospitality sector.The Northern Ireland Hospitality School, as a delivery partner, was launched last year in conjunction with Northern Regional College . The Trust, over the next three years, has committed almost pound,, offering students a chance to expand their skills and gain guaranteed employment with one of three local hotels – the Tullyglass House Hotel, the Adair Arms and the Galgorm Golf Resort and Spa. Since its launch, a total of  students have completed the Level  Professional Bartending course and have gone on to secure full-time employment. Joel Johnston, a former student of the Northern Ireland Hospitality School, who now works at Gillies Grill as part of the Galgorm Golf Resort and Spa in Ballymena, has been reflecting on his experience.“I’m really glad that the Northern Ireland Hospitality School was able to become a delivery partner with The Gallaher Trust,” Joel said. “Completing the Level  Professional Bartending course has made such a positive impact on my le I was able to develop my skills and now I’m working in a field that I’m truly passionate about.“I have always wanted to work within the hospitality industry and when I saw that a Hospitality School had been launched in Ballymena, I couldn’t wait to apply. “The Professional Bartending course has given me a great launchpad into my career. Working within hospitality can be tough, but the course has equipped me with all the skills necessary to thrive.“I am an employee at Gillies Grill and I’m really enjoying it. The Hospitality School has made such a dference to my le and I’m not sureI would be in this position without it. Any eligible organisation that requires funding and support should definitely apply to become a delivery partner with The Gallaher Trust. Their support helps to get projects off the ground which can make a big impact on the people of Ballymena – just like the Hospitality School.”Elsewhere, Ian Paisley MP, Chairman of The Gallaher Trust says he’s delighted with the success of the Hospitality School thus far and is speaking out to encourage other eligible organisations to apply for funding.“On behalf of The Gallaher Trust, we are so proud that the Hospitality School is achieving its purpose of developing skills and creating jobs for adults within the Ballymena community,” Ian commented.“Our mission at the Trust is to work alongside delivery partners that are aiming to make a real dference in peoples’ lives by creating jobs, developing skills and helping disadvantaged adults.“Delivery partner applications are now open and to be eligible, you must be a charity, a not-for-profit based organisation or a social enterprise, that can make an impact on the greater Ballymena area.“I would strongly urge any organisation that is eligible, to apply for funding today. We have seen from the likes of the Hospitality School, that it could make a massive dference to your project and ultimately the people of Ballymena, which is our clear purpose.”For more information about becoming a delivery partner, visit the Contact Us section of The Gallaher Trust’s website: https:thegallahertrust.org contact-us . Applications for funding and eligibility guidance can also be downloaded from the website.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220327news200 000 pledged to support agricultural shows
story: Outgoing AgricultureMinister Edwin Pootshas announced a pound, package of support for Northern Ireland’s agricultural shows following the Covid- pandemic. Announcing the bounce back support scheme, Mr Poots said: “Many businesses and sectors were adversely affected by the Covid- pandemic, and our agricultural shows were not immune to these effects, with all shows cancelled in  and only a few being able to take place in . This resulted in shows losing the opportunity to raise vital funds that would help prepare for the  season. “Shows play a vital role in showcasing our excellent agri-food produce and supporting our rural communities, as well as boosting our economy and the additional tourism opportunities. These shows are predominately run by many volunteers who give of their free time and I would like to extend my thanks to them for all of their hard work. “Pre-pandemic agricultural shows attracted more than , visitors. It is essential therefore that NI shows have the opportunity to run a full schedule this year to promote and facilitate future economic growth for agri-food businesses and I am pleased that I can support their efforts through the provision of the pound, bounce back support scheme I’ve announced today, which will allow each show to claim up to a maximum of poundk for new or increased costs. “Departmental officials will contact shows directly in the next few weeks to assist them in availing of my support scheme.” Looking to the future, Mr Poots has announced plans for an independent review of local agricultural shows, which will explore the potential for longer term support options and help shows remain sustainable in the years ahead. He added: “Although I am providing support to our local shows this year, I am of the view that Government departments and local councils should consider options for longer term support. “I am therefore announcing plans for an independent review to commence in the next month or two which will aim to explore future support options and guide future policy, in addition to identying new and innovative methods which would be utilised by local shows to help safeguard their future.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220327newshargey tackles digital exclusion through provision of free broadband
story: Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey has announced the provision of free broadband for those facing digital exclusion as a barrier to work. The broadband support package will be available to eligible jobseekers through the Department for Communities’ Adviser Discretion Fund, a grant fund available to help remove barriers to employment that prevent people moving towards and into employment Minister Hargey said: “Digital exclusion has been one of the inequalities thrown into sharper focus by the Covid- pandemic. “More than ever, employers are posting vacancies online, with many having moved to online interviewing and more positions requiring people to work from home. “Therefore, not having access to broadband can be a signicant barrier to searching for, or moving into, employment. “I am tackling this by providing free broadband support which will provide broadband for eligible jobseekers who do not currently have the service.” Support for broadband through the Adviser Discretion Fund is available for a period of six months. The Fund can provide a non-repayable grant of up to pound,, in a  month period, to remove barriers to employment. The Minister continued: “The success of the Adviser Discretion Fund in helping remove barriers to employment has already been seen throughout the year, particularly in the uptake of upfront childcare costs, which I made available last October. “I am delighted that we have already helped around  parents with average upfront childcare costs of approximately pound. “This additional scheme will help remove similar barriers to employment for those facing digital exclusion due to a lack of broadband service.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220329newsbooster third dose milestone welcomed
story: The number of COVID- vaccine boosters and third doses administered in Northern Ireland has passed the one million mark. The milestone has been welcomed by Patricia Donnelly, head of Northern Ireland’s vaccination programme. She said: “GPs, community pharmacists and Trusts have all worked extremely hard to roll out the booster campaign, with the period in the run up to Christmas particularly busy. “They all deserve our heartfelt thanks. Because of the vaccines, we now have much greater protection against the virus. “All those involved in the vaccination programme are genuine history makers.” Booster doses have been provided from the latter stages of last year, supplementing the two primary doses already received. At the same time, a third primary dose was offered to people with a severely weakened immune system, which was then followed by a booster three months after their third primary dose. The latest tallies on Northern Ireland’s vaccination dashboard include , boosters and , third doses. Patriciacontinued: “While demand for vaccines is no longer at levels from the peak of the campaign, people are still coming forward on a daily basis for boosters and first and second doses. “It’s still not too late to get these jabs. Please do so - and benefit from the really important protection they bring.” The one million landmark has been reached with the Spring booster campaign imminent. In line with UK-wide guidance set by the JCVI, the Spring campaign will offer an additional booster dose to: anyone who is aged  or over care home residents and anyone aged  and over who has a severely weakened immune system. Further details can be found on NI Direct:www.nidirect.gov.uk articles get-covid--vaccination-and-booster-northern-ireland

title: northern ireland spring booster vaccination to begin in april who is eligible
story: Northern Ireland#s Spring booster programme is to begin this week: Danny Lawson PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNorthern Ireland#s Spring booster programme is to begin this week: Danny Lawson PA WireAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailNorthern Ireland’s Spring booster vaccination programme is to get under way in the coming days.The Public Health Agency is now encouraging those eligible to book their appointments.Those over , residents in care homes and those over -years-old with a weakened immune system will be offered the added protection against Covid-.Read MoreCoronavirus Northern Ireland: Five deaths and , new casesIt’s advised that the booster should be offered around six months after an inidual received their first booster dose.Dr Jillian Johnston, Joint Interim Assistant Director in Health Protection at the PHA, said: “COVID- is more serious in older people and those with a weakened immune system. Protection from the vaccine may be lower and may decline more quickly in these people.”She explained that while vaccines provide good protection against severe Covid- disease, protection against the Omicron iant seems to decline quickly even after a booster dose.She said the spring booster dose would help to address this.“This spring booster is being offered as a precaution to those at extremely high risk, most of whom received their first booster around six months ago. If the number of infections increases over the summer, this booster should help to reduce your risk of being admitted to hospital with Covid-.”The spring booster programme will begin in care homes from the start of April and will be carried out by community pharmacies.GPs will invite all their eligible patients who are aged over  for vaccination.They will also have the option to receive the booster at a participating community pharmacy or at a HSC Trust-led vaccination clinic.Health Trusts will also continue to run some vaccination centres as well as mobile clinics pop-up clinics.District nursing teams will continue to vaccinate the eligible housebound patients.Immunosuppressed iniduals are also eligible for the spring booster as long as there is at least three months since their previous dose.The Public Health Agency say Trust clinicians should write to advise their patients of this while GPs should provide a “safety net” service.Practices will be able to offer vaccination to any of their registered patients who meet the criteria of immunosuppressed at patient request of by practice identication.“COVID- has not gone away and we would urge those eligible to come forward for the spring booster when invited,” added Dr Johnston.Further infromation is available online at www.pha.site springbooster or by visit the NI Direct website.Most ReadTwo arrested and title: sdlp leader colum eastwood condemns attempts to intimidate candidates
story: SDLP Leader Colum Eastwood MP. Pic: Press EyeSDLP candidate Paul Doherty. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSDLP Leader Colum Eastwood MP. Pic: Press EyeAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe SDLP leader Colum Eastwood has condemned a string of attempts to intimidate his party across Northern Ireland.It follows an incident on Monday night, where the SDLP’s West Belfast Assembly candidate and food bank director Paul Doherty said his team was approached by a group of men on the Shankill Road who told them they were not welcome in the area.Dissapointed to be approached by a group of men on the Shankill this evening and told that we weren#t welcome. This won#t deter me from continuing to work for people in this community. I am running to represent everyone in West Belfast. @sdlplive pic HUmgSjMT— Paul DohertyMarch , In east Belfast, the SDLP’s Charlotte Carson also had election posters set on fire on Cyprus Avenue on Monday which required the Fire Service to attend.SDLP election poster on fire on Cyprus Avenue, east Belfast. Fire Service just arrived at the scene @UTVNews pic ZLAJpNuSf— Judith HillMarch , The SDLP’s Strangford candidate Conor Houston also had more than  posters stolen in the Newtownards area at the end of last week.In a statement, Mr Eastwood said: “SDLP candidates are out every day serving their communities and working hard to build a better future for all our people. These attacks on our party, our candidates and our campaign are totally futile - we have come under attack from violent thugs before. We have beaten them every time. We will beat them again.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He criticised those seeking to make the election campaign “a toxic race to the bottom on protocol and identity politics.”“They want to stop us reaching out to the people across all our communities who are begging for help to heat their homes and feed their kids - real problems that transcend political or community background,” he said. Wherever people need help, the SDLP will be there for them. We won’t back down.”He noted the “outrageous” attacks were also focused on a new generation of SDLP leaders.“Paul Doherty - a food bank director feeding hundreds of families every week and delivering humanitarian aid to Ukrainian civilians. “Charlotte Carson - a teacher in an integrated school with a passion for empowering young women and girls. Conor Houston - a man who has dedicated his le to reconciliation and peace building between our communities.“Our candidates are a threat to no one but those who want to keep us all in the past. Paul, Charlotte and Conor are shattering old certainties, they are stepping up and stepping in to put people first. And they will have my support every step of the way.”Posting a video on Twitter, Paul Doherty said he and his colleagues were approached by a group of men as they were putting up posters on the Shankill Road.We were approached by a group of men who said we weren’t welcome in this area and threatened that our posters would be taken down,” he said.What was even more frustrating was the fact that we tried to engage and have a conversation about what really matters.”He said this included issues like health, housing and the cost-of-living.But they were too concerned about certain rhetoric around the protocol. This narrative isn’t representative of the views of many I know and have supported here in this community,” he said.And it won’t deter us to continue to work for people in these areas,” adding that he was standing to represent everyone in the community regardless of their political outlook.It’s time we toned down this toxic political rhetoric and focus on the issues that really matter.”Most ReadTwo Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumDUP running out of time to catch Sinn Fein but vote-shares don’t always translate to Assembly seatsBill WhiteExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSinn Fein Stormont leader Michelle O#Neill. Pic: Jonathan McCambridge PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSinn Fein Stormont leader Michelle O#Neill. Pic: Jonathan McCambridge PA WireMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe results are in from our Spring  NI ‘Tracker’ poll, and we see that Sinn Fein are still comfortably in the lead as Northern Ireland’s largest party on a projected % vote share - up a % point from our Winter poll in January.Sinn Fein have now been the lead party in all polls for some time, and so they must be really hoping that they can achieve top spot in the May  election.The DUP are up two points in second place on %, and are seven points behind Sinn Fein.The other two unionist parties have dropped a bit, with the UUP on % - down a point since our January poll, and the TUV on % . Even so, this % score is still three times more than the TUV achieved in the last NI Assembly election in .So the trend is good for the DUP with perhaps some of their regular voters who moved to the TUV ing to the fold as the Assembly election approaches.However they still have a big gap to make upthey are to catch Sinn Fein, and there’s not much time left.The SDLP are at least consistent in the polls, coming in this time at % - no change from our Winter poll in January.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up  Read MoreLucidTalk opinion poll: Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill nudges closer to top Stormont post as DUP lags behindThe SDLP has been showing around the %-% vote-share mark for a long time, with no real up or down movement either way. Alliance are at %, up  points, perhaps benefiting from the UUP’s small drop.About this UUP drop, it’s noteworthy that Doug Beattie’s personal ‘leader rating’ in this poll was down  points from his January poll score, which is a hefty drop.Perhaps the Twitter posts controversy has been a factor here, and interestinglythis seems to have had more of a negative impact with female voters than males.Boris Johnson had the biggest increase in our ‘leader ratings’ - up  points from his January poll-score. This reflects the national UK-wide polls with the PM benefiting from a ‘Ukraine war bounce’. However, he still remains Northern Ireland’s lowest rated political leader at minus !Now the science of opinion polling applies to modelling and forecasting NI-wide public opinion, ie projecting vote-shares – that’s what polls do, and they usually do this pretty accurately.Read MoreSuzanne Breen:OpinionWith five weeks to go until Northern Ireland election, Sinn Fein remain in pole positionJon Tonge:OpinionAlliance on course to be third biggest party in the NI ExecutiveBut, of course, what people really want to knowis how all these vote-shares would translate into seats at the Assembly election.As the political commentators will tell you, vote-shares don’t always translate neatly into NI Assembly seats.Indeed, it’s perfectly possible for the TUV to get a %-% NI-Wide vote-share in this election, and for Jim Allister to still be the only TUV MLA – although, with that NI vote-share, they would have to be a bit unlucky for that to happen. It’s all down to where, and in what constituencies, the votes come from.So for our last pre-NI Assembly election pollwe will be running  separate NI constituency polls with the named candidates and parties for each constituency, presented to each poll respondent.Basically the poll-participants will be presented with actual ballot they will see in each of their respective constituencies on election day. Then, like we do with all our polls, we will combine all this data into NI-wide political-party vote-share projections.This approach brings in some of the reality of the election, as there’s always a brand and loyalty factor with some named candidates. We used this approach in our very last pre- UK general election poll, and we believe it was one of the factors that allowed us to forecast that election to within %. We will seeit works as well again – we hope it does!Bill White is managing director of Belfast polling and market research company LucidTalkRelated topicsNorthern Ireland AssemblySinn FéinUlster Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandUKRepublic of IrelandWorldPoliticsBrexitHealthEducationCourtsObituariesArchiveBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Locking up ‘main man in UK’ for Kinahan gang is a signicant victoryExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseConvicted: Thomas Kavanagh. Credit: NCA PAPADaniel Canning. Credit: NCA PAPAGary Vickery. Credit: NCA PAPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueConvicted: Thomas Kavanagh. Credit: NCA PARobin SchillerMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe -year jail term handed down to the Kinahan cartel’s “main man in the UK” marks a signicant victory in the fight against the international drugs gang.Thomas ‘Bomber’ Kavanaghoperated a lucrative network which saw more than €m worth of drugs hidden inside industrial machinery being smuggled into the UK in a single year.However, the high-ranking associate will be out of circulation until he is well into his s, when he is released on licence from the longest jail term he has received in a criminal career spanning over five decades.Born on September , , Kavanagh grew up in south central Dublin and was on the garda radar by the time he turned .In April  he picked up his first criminal conviction, and over the next  years was regularly in the dock for offences involving firearms, burglary, making threats to kill and assault.By the turn of the century, he was considered a serious player in organised crime and came into the sights of the recently formed Criminal Assets Bureau .The Bureau later secured an order for more than £, in unpaid taxes from the proceeds of his criminality.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up As a result of the increasing garda pressure, Kavanagh moved his family to the English Midlands in the early s, eventually settling in Tamworth, near Birmingham.He set up TK Motors in  which bought cars at auction before exporting them for profit to Ireland. Investigators believe he made “quite considerable” s from this enterprise which included trading cars across Europe and even in Dubai. However, they suspect he relied mainly on crime to fund his lestyle.While in the UK, gardaí suspect ‘Bomber’ was also linked to major drug shipments imported into Ireland through his contacts across continental Europe.By  his wealth was growing and that year he used fake documents to re-mortgage his £, home, a fraud for which he later received a fully suspended -month sentence. The house was lavishly refurbished, while a state-of-the-art security system, fortied gates, reinforced doors and bullet proof glass were also installed.His influence had also expanded across the Midlands and the National Crime Agencyassessed that his rise led to him becoming the Kinahans’ “figurehead” and “top man” in the UK. While his Europe-wide empire grew, garda intelligence in late  indicated that Kavanagh was rarely,ever, sighted in Ireland. That changed after February , , when his brother-in-law David Byrne was shot dead at the Regency Hotel in Drumcondra. Byrne was considered a close associate of the Kinahan gang in Dublin along with his older brother Liam. The murder would lead to a spate of gun murders, with  people killed in Ireland and Spain.He was a prominent mourner at the funeral  days later where he was joined by associates including feud killer Freddie Thompson and the Kinahan brothers Daniel and Christy Jnr. Also at the funeral service was an unknown middle-aged man, who garda inquiries would later determine was Declan Brady.Gardaí immediately began investigating the unassuming haulier who became known as ‘Mr Nobody’ and would turn out to be Kavanagh’s man in Ireland.The following January, Irish detectives raided a business in Dublin’s Greenogue industrial estate where they found ‘Mr Nobody’ along with two other men and an arsenal of high-powered weapons. More than €m worth of drugs were also seized in a later search.Financial documents led back to a logistics firm in the Midlands linked to Dublin brothers-in-law Gary Vickeryand Daniel Canning .As part of Operation Hornstay, a search at Dover Port in October  led to drugs worth €m hidden inside industrial machinery being seized, and the two men were arrested.Examinations of their devices showed they were receiving instructions from a man referred to as ‘The Gaffer’.Investigators also had to decipher the codewords used “Paper” was money, “Phones” were blocks of cocaine, “Sister’ was the machinery”, “Jelly” referred to Vickery while “Smiley” was Canning.In one email a week before the Dover bust ‘The Gaffer’ told his subordinates: “Ta put safe in sister and jelly b on in couple hours did not want to get him up tis morning from beauty sleep :”.The NCA established that this man was Thomas Kavanagh, who also used the alias Paul Christopher Harvey.The father of six was arrested at Birmingham airport on January , , while ing from a family holiday in Mexico.An encrypted BQ Aquaris device was found in his suitcase, indicating the cartel associate conducted business while on holiday.His luxury home was searched, and cash totalling £,, expensive watches, jewellery and luxury clothing seized. Weapons were also found, including knives, bats, and a pink stun gun disguised as a torch — for which he received a three-year jail term.More trouble was to come when he was charged along with Vickery and Canning in relation to the drugs importation conspiracy.The NCA suspects they imported €m worth of drugs into the UK between September  and October .​​​Judge Martyn Levett jailed him for  years at Ipswich Crown Court yesterday. Vickery and Canning were given prison terms of  and -and-a-half years respectively for their roles in the syndicate.All three will serve half of their sentences out on licence.After the hearing, NCA deputy director Matt Horne described Kavanagh as a “high-ranking member of the Kinahan cartel” and “their main man in the UK”.They will now go after The Gaffer’s assets, including his Tamworth home and any items bought with the proceeds of crime.Most ReadTwo arrested and murder investigation launched after man’s death in NewtownabbeyWatch: Paul Gascoigne caught on camera tripping up child REUTERS Gleb GaranichREUTERSUkrainian President Volodymyr ZelenskyPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA Ukrainian serviceman walks near the wreck of a Russian tank on the front line in the Kyiv region, Ukraine March , . REUTERS Gleb GaranichLisa SmythTwitterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThree quarters of Sinn Fein voters want the Republic of Ireland to maintain its policy of military neutrality, a poll has found.Only % of Sinn Fein supporters were in favour of Ireland dropping it and joining Nato in the context of the Ukraine war.However, overall, a third of people responding to the LucidTalk survey want the Republic of Ireland to drop neutrality and join and support Nato.At the same time, % of respondents of the poll have said the Republic should remain neutral as Russia continues its bombardment of Ukraine.Around one in seven who responded to the survey for the Belfastsaid the Republic should drop its policy of neutrality but not join Nato, while continuing to support EU foreign policy.Read MoreRevealed: One in seven people in Northern Ireland willing to host refugees escaping the war in UkraineIt comes just days after the Ukrainian president appeared to criticise Ireland for not abandoning its policy or neutrality despite Russia’s brutal invasion of the country.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Addressing the European Council last week, Volodymyr Zelensky name-checked EU member states — noting in turn what he saw as the level of support the country had given Ukraine.He said: “Lithuania stands for us. Latvia stands for us. Estonia stands for us. Poland stands for us. France — Emanuel, I really believe that you will stand for us. Slovenia stands for us. Slovakia stands for us.“The Czech Republic stands for us. Romania knows what dignity is, so it will stand for us at the crucial moment. Bulgaria stands for us. Greece, I believe, stands with us.“Germany... A little later. Portugal — well, almost... Croatia stands for us. Sweden — yellow and blue should always stand together. Finland — I know you are with us. The Netherlands stands for the rational, so we’ll find common ground. Malta — I believe we will succeed. Denmark — I believe we will succeed. Luxembourg — we understand each other. Cyprus — I really believe you are with us.“Italy — thank you for your support! Spain — we’ll find common ground. Belgium — we will find arguments. Austria, together with Ukrainians, it is an opportunity for you. I’m sure of it. Ireland — well, almost.”The Ukrainian leader offered no further reasons for his comment.While fully backing the Ukrainian push for EU membership, Ireland has not abandoned its position of military neutrality in the face of the Russian assault.EU leaders have so far resisted the call to accelerate the accession of Ukraine to the bloc.Taoiseach Micheal Martin has since played down Zelensky’s comments, claiming the Ukrainian leader was talking in terms of the ‘European perspective’.Related topicsSinn FéinUkraineLucidTalk pollMore On Sinn Féin PremiumJust £k spent as multi-million pound title: renewable energy chief says climate goals need radical action
story: Hilda Nakabuye, centre, a Fridays for Future activist from Uganda, talks with Annalena Baerbock, German foreign minister, and Robert Habeck, federal minister for economic affairs and climate protection  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueHilda Nakabuye, centre, a Fridays for Future activist from Uganda, talks with Annalena Baerbock, German foreign minister, and Robert Habeck, federal minister for economic affairs and climate protection By Frank Jordans, APMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe world needs to take “radical action” to sht away from fossil fuels and ensure global warming does not pass dangerous thresholds, the head of the International Renewable Energy Agencyhas said.The agency’s -page report concluded that investments of . trillion dollarsin renewable energy are needed globally each year until  to reduce emissions and meet the goals of the Paris climate accord.Currently, those emissions are going up, not down.Francesco La Camera, the director-general of Irena, told an energy conference in Berlin: “The energy transition is far from being on track and anything short of radical action in the coming years will diminish, even eliminate chances to meet our climate goals.”Countries agreed seven years ago in Paris to limit global warming to C– and ideally no more than .C– to avoid potentially catastrophic consequences for the entire planet.A recent report by a UN science  found that with temperatures already more than .C above the pre-industrial average, billions of people around the world are vulnerable to impacts from climate change."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news aec .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bc-f-c-ef-ee_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news aec .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bc-f-c-ef-ee_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news aec .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bc-f-c-ef-ee_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news aec .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bc-f-c-ef-ee_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Hilda Nakabuye, Fridays for Future activist, speaks at the opening of the Berlin Energy Transition Dialogue at the Federal Foreign Office AP PA Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueHilda Nakabuye, Fridays for Future activist, speaks at the opening of the Berlin Energy Transition Dialogue at the Federal Foreign Office Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Mr La Camera told the Berlin Energy Transition Dialogue that “not only the .C, the C goal is really in dangerwe don’t act and don’t make a dramatic change in the way we produce and consume energy”.Abu Dhabi-based Irena suggested that investments of  billion dollarsshould be erted away from the fossil fuel sector annually to avoid creating wells, pipelines and power plants that cannot be used any more.This was echoed by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, who called for an end to private sector financing for coal power, which surged to record highs last year.“Lenders need to recognise that coal and fossil fuels are futile investments that will lead to billions of dollars in stranded assets,” he said.With some countries ramping up domestic fossil fuel production amid energy price hikes and fears of supply shortages because of Russia’s war in Ukraine, Mr Guterres urged governments not to delay the sht away from fossil fuels.“The current crisis shows that we must accelerate, not slow, the renewable energy transition,” he said.“This is the only true path to energy security.”Most ReadTwo
